user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_ip_addr_to_key:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
MHD_ip_addr_to_key (const struct sockaddr_storage *addr,
                    socklen_t addrlen,
                    struct MHD_IPCount *key)
{
  memset (key,
          0,
          sizeof(*key));

  /* IPv4 addresses */
  if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in) <= (size_t) addrlen)
  {
    if (AF_INET == addr->ss_family)
    {
      key->family = AF_INET;
      memcpy (&key->addr.ipv4,
              &((const struct sockaddr_in *) addr)->sin_addr,
              sizeof(((const struct sockaddr_in *) NULL)->sin_addr));
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }

#ifdef HAVE_INET6
  if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in6) <= (size_t) addrlen)
  {
    /* IPv6 addresses */
    if (AF_INET6 == addr->ss_family)
    {
      key->family = AF_INET6;
      memcpy (&key->addr.ipv6,
              &((const struct sockaddr_in6 *) addr)->sin6_addr,
              sizeof(((const struct sockaddr_in6 *) NULL)->sin6_addr));
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }
#endif

  /* Some other address */
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious fragments: 
- The only pointer parameters are "const struct sockaddr_storage *addr" and "struct MHD_IPCount *key". "addr" is already const-qualified (as required by Rule 8.13). "key" is intentionally non-const because the function writes into it (memset, assignments, memcpy destination), so it must not be const. 
- All casts from addr use const-qualified target types (e.g. (const struct sockaddr_in *) addr and (const struct sockaddr_in6 *) addr), so pointers derived from addr are const-qualified. The memcpy sources are obtained from those const-qualified members and therefore supply const-qualified source pointers to memcpy. 
- The use of ((const struct sockaddr_in *) NULL)->sin_addr and the analogous IPv6 sizeof expression only appear in sizeof and do not constitute dereferencing at runtime; they also use const-qualified pointer types. 
- No other pointer declarations or usages in this function could reasonably be made const without preventing necessary modifications.
Therefore there are no code fragments here that require further investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13.
